qas.question: How long have Alpine crystals been studied and collected?
When did the alpine crystals begin to be classified?
Who studied the shapes of crystals?
By the 19th century what was common in the Alpine regions?

context: Alpine crystals have been studied and collected for <a0_0>hundreds of years<a0_0/>, and began to be classified in <a1_0>the 18th century<a1_0/>. <a2_0>Leonhard Euler<a2_0/> studied the shapes of crystals, and by the 19th century <a3_0>crystal hunting<a3_0/> was common in Alpine regions. <a4_0>David Friedrich Wiser<a4_0/> amassed a collection of 8000 crystals that he studied and documented. In the 20th century Robert Parker wrote a well-known work about the rock crystals of the Swiss Alps; at the same period a commission was established to control and standardize the naming of Alpine minerals.
